brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a specific inspection in the CDI framework. It reports @Interceptor classes that do not specify at least one interceptor binding type, which is a requirement for proper functioning.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'interceptor_without_binding_type' checks all classes in the project. If a class has the '@Interceptor' annotation, it asserts that there exists at least one binding type specified in the '@Interceptor' annotation. If no binding type is found, it generates a message indicating that the '@Interceptor' class does not specify any binding type.
PRE_model_validation: The rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions provided, such as 'getClasses', 'hasAnnotation', 'exists', 'getAnnoAttrNames', 'NOT', 'isEmpty', and 'getFQN'. The rule logic is sound as it checks for the existence of at least one binding type in '@Interceptor' annotated classes.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://docs.jboss.org/weld/reference/latest/en-US/html/interceptors.html
Summary: This page from JBoss Weld documentation provides detailed information about interceptors in CDI, including the requirement for specifying binding types.

2. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/java-cdi
Summary: This tutorial on Baeldung explains the basics of CDI, including the use of interceptors and the importance of binding types.
